Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, an existing custody and parenting-time order may be modified when a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred and modification is in the best interests of the children.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion is a custody appeal focused on the need for explicit findings regarding domestic violence and its effect on the child. It does not address the standard for *modifying* an existing custody or parenting-time order, nor does it discuss the requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances. The case instead concerns initial/supplementary custody determinations and the proper consideration of domestic violence, so it is not authority for the modification standard stated in the proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, an existing custody and parenting-time order may be modified when a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred and modification is in the best interests of the children.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a removal/relocation request under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in a joint custody context, and the standard applied is whether removal is in the children’s best interests. While the court does quote ALI Principles noting that relocation can constitute a substantial change in circumstances, the case does not set out or apply the general Massachusetts standard for modification of existing custody/parenting-time orders (i.e., material and substantial change plus best interests). The modification framework is only mentioned indirectly via the ALI commentary and is not the holding of the case.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002) ... state in pertinent part: “(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances ... only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce] .... (4) When a relocation constituting changed circumstances ... renders it impractical to maintain the same proportion of custodial responsibility to each parent, the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests ... .”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, an existing custody and parenting-time order may be modified when a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred and modification is in the best interests of the children.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion is a direct appeal from an original divorce and custody judgment, not from a complaint to modify an existing custody or parenting-time order. The court discusses the best-interests standard and affirms the trial judge’s original custody and visitation determinations, but it does not address the legal standard or prerequisites for modifying a prior custody or visitation order based on a material and substantial change in circumstances. Thus, it does not provide authority for the modification proposition stated.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings, which are founded on the evidence.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that the “polar star” and “overriding concern” of the Probate and Family Court in custody matters is the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly discusses that the governing standard in custody cases is the ‘best interests of the child’ and notes that this standard has long been used in Massachusetts. However, it does not use the phrases “polar star” or “overriding concern,” nor does it frame the Probate and Family Court’s role in those specific terms. Thus, while it supports the longevity and centrality of the best-interests standard, it does not support the exact quoted formulation in the proposition.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history, dating back to the Nineteenth Century. … The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002) … (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”}

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly applies the "best interests of the child" standard and discusses deference to the trial judge in custody/adoption matters, but it does not use the "polar star" or "overriding concern" language or explicitly characterize best interests in those historical terms. The case therefore illustrates that best interests is the governing standard, but it is not good authority for the specific quoted proposition about Massachusetts courts having long recognized it as the "polar star" and "overriding concern" of the Probate and Family Court.

Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766\u.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that the “polar star” and “overriding concern” of the Probate and Family Court in custody matters is the best interests of the child.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766\u.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses parental fitness, the Commonwealth’s policy on family integrity, and the relationship between parental fitness and the child’s best interests, but it does not state or characterize the ‘best interests of the child’ as the Probate and Family Court’s ‘polar star’ or ‘overriding concern.’ The quoted sections focus on standards for state intervention (parental unfitness, clear and convincing evidence) rather than articulating best interests as the central guiding principle in custody cases. Thus, this case does not directly support the specific proposition as phrased.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766\u.relevant_excerpt: “State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection.” … “In that sense, the fitness of parents and the best interests of the child are related. … ‘[T]he critical question is whether the natural parents are currently fit to further the welfare and best interests of the child.’”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The Defendant’s unilateral decision-making regarding extracurricular activities during the Plaintiff’s parenting time is inconsistent with the parties’ joint legal custody, which obligates them to share in major decisions affecting the children’s welfare and to cooperate in parenting decisions.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the meaning of joint legal custody only in the context of defining it under Mass. G.L. c. 208, § 31, while resolving a removal and physical custody dispute. It does not address parental decision‑making about extracurricular activities, nor does it discuss whether one parent’s unilateral decisions during the other’s parenting time are inconsistent with joint legal custody. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about unilateral extracurricular decision-making conflicting with joint legal custody obligations.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The judge did award joint or shared legal custody, which G. L. c. 208, § 31 (1984 ed.), defines as ‘a continued mutual responsibility and involvement by both parents in decisions regarding the child’s welfare in matters of education, medical care, emotional, moral and religious development.’ As we have said, he awarded physical custody, or possession of the children, to the wife.”

Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 815.raw_text: Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 815–16 (1981)
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 815.proposition: The Defendant’s disparaging comments and his practice of blaming the Plaintiff in front of the children for scheduling disagreements is contrary to the 2022 Order, contrary to the children’s best interests, and inconsistent with the requirement that each parent foster and encourage the children’s relationship with the other parent.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 815.support_reasoning: The case concerns a custodial parent’s request to remove children from Massachusetts and sets out factors for evaluating removal in light of the children’s best interests and the custodial parent’s well‑being. It does not address disparaging comments, blame‑shifting in front of children, or any requirement that each parent affirmatively foster the children’s relationship with the other parent. Thus it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about the defendant’s disparaging conduct or co‑parenting obligations.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 815.relevant_excerpt: “From what we can ascertain, the judge recognized the importance of the ‘frequent and continuing contact’ of the child with both its parents … and entered his judgment prohibiting removal on the basis that the move would make visitation more difficult. We consider that factor not in itself conclusive. The best interests of children for purposes of deciding whether to permit removal are also interwoven with the well being of the custodial parent, and the determination, therefore, requires that the interests of the mother also be taken into account.”

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that when the parties’ inability to cooperate on significant parenting issues or one parent’s interference with the other’s relationship with the children materially affects the children’s welfare, modification of custody may be appropriate.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion affirms that custody determinations and modifications turn on the child’s welfare, and it upholds a change awarding sole custody to the father with no visitation to the mother based on the parents’ conflict and the mother’s conduct, which produced a harmful “tug-of-war” and emotional and physical reactions in the child. While the court does not use the modern “co-parenting” terminology, the reasoning squarely ties modification to the impact of the parties’ conflicting approaches and the mother’s interference on the child’s welfare, consistent with the proposition. However, it is somewhat general and framed in best‑interests terms rather than an explicit doctrinal rule about inability to cooperate, so confidence is medium.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “The period of time covered by the several modifications of the court order granting the mother visitation rights coincided with a period of increasing differences between the parents over the visitations as they affected the child. There were captures and recaptures of the child in New York and Boston in circumstances which were harmful to the child and which caused emotional and physical reactions in the child commensurate with these distresses… The child suffered from that tug-of-war… If given custody or even visitation rights, the mother would continue the same teachings to the child.”

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that when the parties’ inability to cooperate on significant parenting issues or one parent’s interference with the other’s relationship with the children materially affects the children’s welfare, modification of custody may be appropriate.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The case is a removal/relocation decision applying the Yannas ‘real advantage’ framework, not a custody-modification case based on parental noncooperation or one parent’s interference. While the opinion mentions the mother’s possible motive to interfere with the father’s relationship, it does so only as a factor in assessing ‘real advantage’ and best interests within a relocation context. It does not discuss or endorse modification of custody as a remedy when such interference or inability to cooperate materially affects the children’s welfare, so it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “We recognize that removal of a child is not defensible if undertaken ‘to deprive the noncustodial parent of reasonable visitation.’ Yannas, 395 Mass. at 711. In the present case, the judge’s findings regarding a possible motive in this regard are unclear. He stated that he found credible ‘the evidence that suggests that Mother’s decision to move may be motivated by a desire to interfere with Father’s relationship with the minor children’ (emphasis supplied).”
